instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2532: What is 820-2532? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Green light on charger: 18.5V
Current: 0.37 A

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL>: 3.30 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>: 0 volts - no short

<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>

1: 0 - no short
2: 0
3: 2
4: 5
5: 2.03
6: .748

7: 3.34
8: 3.33
9: 7.66
10: 3.38
11: 3.33
12: 0.14


13: 3.32 19: 0
14: 2.00 20: 0
15: 0 21: 0
16: 12.58 22: 4.54
17: 5 23: 0
18: 0 24: 0


L7220: no short

<TRANSISTOR>Q7210</TRANSISTOR>: 5: 0 volts (<SIGNAL>P5V_S3_EN</SIGNAL>)
2: 3.42

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>: 0 V

Follow: <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_EN</SIGNAL> ?

Does <SIGNAL>P5V_S3_EN</SIGNAL> missing mean that the enable is not on? vs something wrong with <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green light, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is controlled by MCP.
Do you get 1.05V at L7770?
If not, change <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>.

BTW, check resistance to ground at L6995, in ohm scale.
Any value lower than 30K will point to bad MCP; 95% of "chance".
